questions.text: A patient presents with a tingling sensation in both legs, polyuria, and weight loss. Based on the given bone marrow aspirate findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Multiple myeloma with renal failure:

  • The bone marrow aspirate shows intranuclear inclusions known as Dutcher's bodies, which are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma often presents with renal failure, polyuria (due to hypercalcemia), and tingling sensations (due to amyloid deposition or hypercalcemia-related neuropathy).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not show Dutcher bodies on bone marrow biopsy.

questions.text:
Match the following blood products with their shelf lives.


	
		
			
			a.
			
			
			1-Granulocytes
			
			
			A- 5 days
			
		
		
			
			b.
			
			
			2- PRBC
			
			
			B- 24 hours
			
		
		
			
			c.
			
			
			3- SDP
			
			
			C- 42 days
			
		
		
			
			d.
			
			
			4- CRYO
			
			
			D- 1 year
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D:

  1. Granulocyte concentrate: They have a very short shelf life of 24 hours.

  2. PRBC (Packed Red Blood Cells): Packed Red Blood cells have a shelf life of 35 to 42 days, depending on the anti-coagulant used: 21 days (ACD/CPD), 35 days (CPDA) and 42 days (SAGM).

  3. SDP (Single Donor Platelets): Single Donor Platelets have a shelf life of 5 days,

  4. CRYO (Cryoprecipitate): Cryoprecipitate has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of Hemophilia B?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fresh frozen plasma:

  • Hemophilia B, also known as Christmas disease, is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of clotting factor IX.
  • Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) contains all the clotting factors, including factor IX, and is used to treat hemophilia B.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Cryoprecipitate, Factor 8, and tranexamic acid are used in the treatment of hemophilia A, not hemophilia B.

questions.text:
In a trauma patient with an unknown blood group who is unstable and requires urgent blood transfusion, which type of blood should be transfused?


	A positive
	AB positive
	O positive
	O negative
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 4 only

Explanation:

In a trauma patient with an unknown blood group, the O negative blood group is typically transfused as it is the universal donor blood type. It can be safely transfused to individuals with any blood type without causing adverse reactions.

Incorrect Options:

A-positive: A positive blood can only be transfused to individuals who are A-positive or AB-positive. Without knowing the patient's blood type, this could cause transfusion reaction.

AB-positive: The AB-positive blood type is known as the universal recipient, meaning a person with AB-positive blood can receive any blood type. However, it is not a universal donor type and can only be given to AB-positive patients.

O-positive: cannot be given due to risk of Rh sensitization in Rh-negative patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction?

choices.text: No improvement in Hb despite transfusion

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cola-colored urine after 2 hrs

  • Cola-colored urine is not a typical presentation in delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions. Instead, urine color typically ranges from red to brown during hemolysis. Additionally, delayed reactions typically occur after 2-3 days or even a few weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C: Raised LDH, Raised indirect bilirubin, and No improvement in Hb despite transfusion are all features of delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: How does Total plasma exchange help in the management of TTP

choices.text: TPE removes the Von Willebrand factor
TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

Explanation:

  • Total plasma exchange (TPE) is a key treatment for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP); it removes the autoantibodies against ADAMTS13. (Option B ruled out)
  • ADAMTS13 is a protease that cleaves von Willebrand factor, preventing the formation of large, thrombogenic von Willebrand factor multimers. (Option A ruled out)
  • This helps restore normal ADAMTS13 activity and reduces the microvascular clotting that characterizes TTP.

Treatment of TTP

Plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroid therapy.
  • It is the mainstay of treatment in TTP.
  • Corticosteroids operate by decreasing the activity of the reticuloendothelial system as well as decreasing autoantibody production.
  • Both the ultra-large VWF multimers and the ADAMTS13 autoantibodies are effectively removed from circulation by plasma exchange therapy.
  • The recommended volume of exchange is one estimated plasma volume (usually 40 mL/kg of body weight) with each treatment.
  • The recommended dose for corticosteroids is 1 mg/kg per day of prednisolone.

Rituximab

An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody was found to help treat TTP refractory to PEX. It targets B-lymphocytes and has a good response rate in refractory and relapsed TTP.

Caplacizumab
  • It has a high potential for TTP.
  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (a bivalent, variable-domain-only fragment) that attacks the A1 section of VWF and prevents platelet adhesion.

Others
  • Splenectomy,
  • Vincristine,
  • Cyclosporine and
  • Cyclophosphamide.

TPE replenishes the coagulation factor (Option D): TPE does not replenish coagulation factors; instead, it removes harmful substances like autoantibodies against ADAMTS13 in TTP, where clotting issues stem from defective vWF cleavage, not coagulation factor deficiencies.

questions.text: What is the commonest cause of a hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Factor V Leiden mutation

Explanation:

  • The most common inherited cause of a hypercoagulable state (predisposing to thrombosis) is the Factor V Leiden mutation.
  • Mutation: Factor V becomes resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C, disrupting the antithrombotic pathway.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.

Primary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Common causes
  • Factor V mutation (Factor V Leiden)
  • Prothrombin mutation (G20210A) - It is comparatively less common than Factor V mutation (Option D ruled out)
  • Elevated factor levels (VIII, IX, XI, or fibrinogen)

Rare causes
  • Antithrombin III deficiency (Option A ruled out)
  • Protein C deficiency (Option B ruled out)
  • Protein S deficiency

Very rare causes
  • Fibrinolysis Defects
  • Homozygous Homocystinuria

Secondary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Major risk factors
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn)
  • Cancer
  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • DIC
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Prolonged rest or immobilisation

Additional risk factors for thrombosis
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum)
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Smoking

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department with a large lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident, you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thromboelastography

Explanation:

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a coagulation test that evaluates the entire coagulation pathway, including both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways and fibrinolysis. It offers a comprehensive assessment of clot formation, clot strength, and clot breakdown.

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate coagulation profiles and guide management with transfusions and hemostatic therapies.

  • Studies show that TEG can reduce blood product usage by up to 40%, decrease postoperative length of stay, and lower the risk of reoperation.
  • TEG measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as clotting occurs. The resulting data is plotted on a graph with time on the x-axis and amplitude (clot strength) on the y-axis. Key values include:
    • Reaction time (R): The time it takes for the clot strength to reach an amplitude of 2 mm.
    • Kinetics (K): The time from R to when the amplitude reaches 20 mm.
    • α-angle: The angle formed by a line from R to the point where K intersects with the 20 mm amplitude mark.
    • Maximum amplitude (MA): The highest amplitude reached.
    • Lysis at 30 minutes (Ly30): The per cent decrease in amplitude 30 minutes after MA (or 60 minutes in some cases).

Inference:

  • A prolonged R time may indicate coagulation factor deficiency or anticoagulation.
  • A decreased α-angle can result from hypofibrinogenemia
  • Low MA can be due to thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction.
  • Increased Ly30 indicates hyperfibrinolysis, often seen in severe trauma or with thrombolytic therapy.

 

Based on the TEG findings, targeted blood products can be administered to normalize coagulation. For example:

  • Fresh frozen plasma for prolonged R time
  • Cryoprecipitate for decreased α-angle
  • Platelets for decreased MA
  • Tranexamic acid or aminocaproic acid for increased Ly30

Incorrect Options:

Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) (Option A) primarily evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

Prothrombin Time (PT) (Option B) mainly assesses the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

Bleeding Time (Option D) measures the duration for bleeding to cease following a standardized skin incision. It primarily evaluates platelet function and primary hemostasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Von Willebrand Disease

Explanation:

Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

  • Types:

vWD type 1

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly

 
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9
  • 2M - VWF dependant platelet adhesion is decreased. There is impairment of VWF binding to platelets. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF:Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) (Option B) is an acquired (not inherited), secondary condition due to systemic activation of the clotting cascade (e.g., in sepsis, trauma, malignancy).

Factor V Deficiency (Option C) is a rare inherited bleeding disorder, also known as parahemophilia. Far less common than vWD.

Hemophilia (A or B) (Option D) is an inherited X-linked recessive disorder involving Factor VIII (A) or Factor IX (B) deficiency. More common in males but still less prevalent than von Willebrand disease.
